What to Say: "Unlike other training programs that start with lectures, we're going to start by touching and examining the actual equipment. This is how you'll learn on the job - by seeing and handling real components.
"A solar power system consists of several key components that work together. Let's examine each one and understand its function.
"First, we have the solar panels or 'الألواح الشمسية' (al-alwah al-shamsiyya). These convert sunlight directly into DC electricity. Notice the different types - monocrystalline, polycrystalline, and thin-film. In Mosul, we typically use mono or poly panels because of their efficiency and durability in our climate.
"Look at these two panels - can you see the difference in quality? The premium panel has a sturdier frame, more even cell coloring, and a better junction box with proper sealing. These differences directly impact performance and lifespan.
"Next is the inverter or 'المحول' (al-muhawwil). This converts the DC electricity from the panels into AC electricity that can power household appliances. There are different types: string inverters for simple systems, hybrid inverters that work with batteries, and microinverters for individual panels.
"For systems that need to store energy, we use batteries or 'البطاريات' (al-battariyyat). In Mosul, we commonly see lead-acid batteries and increasingly lithium-ion batteries. Be very careful about battery quality - there are many refurbished batteries sold as new in our market. This battery here is actually refurbished - notice the uneven weight distribution and marks where it's been opened.
"The charge controller or 'منظم الشحن' (munazzim al-shahn) regulates the charging of batteries from the panels to prevent overcharging.
"All these components are connected using specialized cables and connectors. For DC connections from panels, we use specific solar cable that can withstand UV exposure and high temperatures. Never use regular AC wiring for DC connections - this is a common mistake that can cause fires. Look at this burned wire - this is what happens when standard household cable is used for DC solar connections."
[Allow participants to examine components]
"Now, let's look at the datasheets for these components. Understanding how to read these specifications is critical for proper system design and component matching. This will be a life-saving skill - without it, you might connect incompatible equipment that could fail or even cause fires."
Financial Context to Include: "When comparing components, we need to consider lifetime cost, not just the initial price. For example, a premium inverter from GISAJ may cost 30% more upfront, but if it lasts twice as long and has better efficiency, it will save the customer money. This is called Total Cost of Ownership - we'll learn to calculate this throughout the course.
"Let me show you a concrete example: This standard inverter costs 800,000 IQD and typically lasts 3-4 years in Mosul's climate. This premium inverter costs 1,200,000 IQD but typically lasts 7-8 years. If we divide the cost by years of service:
Standard inverter: 800,000 ÷ 4 years = 200,000 IQD per year Premium inverter: 1,200,000 ÷ 7 years = 171,428 IQD per year
"Even before considering higher efficiency and better reliability, the premium option actually costs less over time. This is the kind of analysis that helps customers make informed decisions."
Stories to Share/Mistakes to Highlight: "Last year, I visited a home in west Mosul where the owner had installed panels himself using standard household AC wire for the DC connections. Within three months, the wires had deteriorated in the sun and caused a short circuit that damaged the inverter. This is why we always use specialized solar DC cable with proper UV protection.
"Look at this photo from an installation in Al-Zanjili neighborhood. The installer used counterfeit MC4 connectors to save about 20,000 IQD. During the first rainy season, water penetrated the poor-quality seals, causing a short circuit that damaged a 1,500,000 IQD inverter. This small 'savings' cost the customer over 75 times what they initially saved."

Q: How do I know if a panel is good quality?
 A: Look for established brands, check the datasheet for certification standards like IEC 61215, and inspect the physical construction - good panels have solid frames, even cell coloring, and quality junction boxes.
Q: How long do solar panels last in Mosul's climate?
 A: Quality panels should last 20-25 years even in our climate, but their output gradually decreases (about 0.5-0.8% per year). The biggest issue in Mosul is dust accumulation, which requires regular cleaning.
Q: What's the difference between cheap and expensive inverters?
 A: Higher quality inverters offer better efficiency, longer warranties, advanced monitoring capabilities, and more reliability in high temperatures and unstable grid conditions - both common in Mosul.
Load Calculation Workshop (11:30-12:30)
Purpose: Teach participants how to accurately measure and calculate a home's electricity consumption in amperes, as commonly used in Mosul.
Materials:

Steps:

Practice measuring different appliances in pairs (20 min)
Complete sample home calculation as full group (10 min)
What to Say: "Accurate load calculation is the foundation of a good solar system design. In Mosul, most people think about their electricity consumption in amperes, not kilowatts, because that's how generator service is sold - by the amp.
"We'll start by measuring actual appliances using these power meters. Simply plug the meter into the outlet, then plug the appliance into the meter. It will display how many watts and amps the device is using.
"Let's look at this load calculation worksheet. We need to record:
Each appliance in the home Its power consumption in amps How many hours per day it runs How many of each appliance are in the home
"This gives us both instantaneous load (how much power is needed at any moment) and daily consumption (how much energy is needed over 24 hours).
"For example, this refrigerator draws 1.5 amps and runs about 8 hours per day (not continuously). So its daily consumption is 1.5 amps × 8 hours = 12 amp-hours.
"When we add up all appliances, we get the total household consumption. For most homes in Mosul, we see between 10-20 amps of continuous load and 80-150 amp-hours of daily consumption.
"Remember that customer in our opening scenario? Ahmed's coffee machine draws 1800 watts. Let's convert that to amps by dividing by 220 volts: 1800 ÷ 220 = 8.2 amps. Just this one appliance uses more than half of his 15-amp connection! This is why accurate load measurement is so important."
Financial Context to Include: "Generator electricity in Mosul now costs about 10,000-12,000 IQD per ampere per month. So a family using 10 amps is spending 100,000-120,000 IQD monthly just on generator electricity. This is crucial information for calculating the return on investment for a solar system.
"For each amp you can offset with solar, you're saving the customer approximately 120,000 IQD per year. This is how we build the financial case for solar investment.
"Let me show you how we turn load calculation into financial analysis:
10 amp connection × 12,000 IQD per amp = 120,000 IQD monthly Annual generator cost: 120,000 × 12 = 1,440,000 IQD 5-year generator cost: 1,440,000 × 5 = 7,200,000 IQD
"Most 10-amp equivalent solar systems cost between 5,000,000-6,000,000 IQD, so the payback period is about 4 years. After that, the customer is essentially getting free electricity. This is a powerful selling point."
Stories to Share/Mistakes to Highlight: "I once designed a system for a family in east Mosul who told me they needed a system for '10 amps' - the same as what they purchased from the neighborhood generator. When I actually measured their usage, I found they were consuming over 15 amps during peak times, which would have led to an undersized system. Always measure actual consumption rather than relying on what customers think they use.
"Look at this photo from a customer in Al-Muhandiseen district. The installer calculated load based on the customer's estimate without measuring anything. Six months later, they had to add additional panels and a larger inverter at significant extra cost. The proper measurement would have added just 15 minutes to the initial assessment but saved over 1,000,000 IQD in upgrade costs."
Common Questions & Answers:
Q: What if the customer buys new appliances after installation?
 A: Always design with some extra capacity (20-30%) to accommodate future growth, and educate customers about system limitations.
Q: How do I handle appliances that draw high power but only run briefly?
 A: Note these separately as "surge" loads. The inverter needs to handle these peak loads even if they're brief.
Q: Can I estimate if I can't measure directly?
 A: Yes, use the reference chart provided, but actual measurements are always more accurate.

What to Say: "Before designing any solar system, we must thoroughly assess the installation site. In Mosul, we have some specific challenges to consider.
"First is orientation and tilt. Ideally, panels should face south in our northern hemisphere location. Using Google Earth, we can determine the roof orientation. Let me show you how to use Google Earth to do a preliminary assessment before visiting the site.
"Second is shading. Any shade on panels dramatically reduces output. In Mosul, we need to consider nearby buildings, water tanks on roofs, satellite dishes, and trees. Using Google Earth's historical imagery feature, we can see shadow patterns throughout the year.
"Third is structural integrity. Many buildings in Mosul have been damaged and repaired. We need to ensure the roof can support the additional weight of the system. For typical residential installations, the panels add about 15-20 kg per square meter.
"Fourth is access and safety. We need clear access to the roof for installation and maintenance, and a safe path for wiring. In Mosul's dense neighborhoods, this can sometimes be challenging.
"Finally, we need to consider dust. Mosul has significant dust issues, especially in summer. Panels should be installed where they can be easily accessed for cleaning.
"Let's look at this photo from an installation in Al-Zuhoor neighborhood. The installer didn't properly assess the site for shading. You can see how the water tank casts a shadow on the panels for several hours each day, reducing system output by nearly 40%."
Financial Context to Include: "A proper site assessment can save thousands of dollars in future problems. For example, if we install on a structurally weak roof that later requires repairs, the cost of dismantling and reinstalling the system can exceed the initial savings of skipping a proper assessment.
"Similarly, a 30% reduction in output due to shading can extend the payback period by years. This is why we never quote a price without visiting the site first.
"Let me show you an example of the financial impact of poor site assessment:
A 5 kW system producing at 100% capacity might generate electricity worth 200,000 IQD per month The same system with 30% shading produces electricity worth only 140,000 IQD per month Over 10 years, this 60,000 IQD monthly loss adds up to 7,200,000 IQD A thorough site assessment might add 100,000 IQD to your project cost but could prevent these massive losses"
Stories to Share/Mistakes to Highlight: "In the Al-Zuhoor neighborhood, I assessed a home that seemed perfect on Google Earth - south-facing roof, no obvious obstructions. But when I visited in person, I discovered a neighbor had built a water tank tower that cast shadows on the roof during winter mornings. This would have reduced system output by nearly 30% during winter. Always verify your Google Earth assessment with an in-person visit.
"Here's a photo from an installation where the structural assessment was inadequate. The roof couldn't support the weight of the system properly, and after six months, water began leaking into the home during rainy periods. The entire system had to be removed, the roof repaired, and the system reinstalled - nearly doubling the installation cost."

 A: For a 3 kW system (common for small homes), you need about 15-20 square meters of unshaded space.
Q: What if the roof isn't perfectly south-facing?
 A: East or west orientations are acceptable but will reduce output by about 15-20%. We can compensate by adding more panels.
Q: How do I determine if a roof is structurally sound?
 A: Look for signs of water damage, cracks, or sagging. When in doubt, consult a structural engineer.

What to Say: "Understanding the difference between DC and AC electrical systems is literally a matter of life and death in solar installations. Most electricians in Iraq are trained primarily for AC systems, but solar requires extensive work with DC electricity, which behaves very differently.
"The key differences:
DC (Direct Current) flows continuously in one direction
AC (Alternating Current) changes direction many times per second (50Hz in Iraq)
"This difference is critical for safety because:
AC naturally extinguishes arcs when it crosses zero volts 100 times per second
DC can sustain arcs indefinitely, reaching temperatures over 3,000°C
"This is why we need special components rated specifically for DC:
"DC-rated circuit breakers have special arc suppression mechanisms "DC cables have thicker insulation and UV protection "DC fuses and disconnects are designed to break DC arcs safely
"Look at these two circuit breakers - they appear similar, but this one is AC-only, while this one is rated for DC. Using the wrong type is one of the most common and dangerous mistakes in solar installation.

DC circuit breakers rated for the system voltage
Properly rated fuses on each string
DC-rated disconnects for maintenance safety
"Wire sizing is especially important. For DC solar circuits, we calculate:
Wire must handle 125% of maximum current
Account for temperature derating in Mosul's hot climate
Consider voltage drop (should be less than 3% total)
"For example, if a string produces 9 amps maximum:

"In a parallel connection, we connect all positive terminals together and all negative terminals together. This adds the current while keeping the voltage the same. So three 30V, 9A panels in parallel would produce 30V at 27A.
"Most systems use a combination of series and parallel. We create 'strings' of panels in series, then connect multiple strings in parallel.
"The critical factor is matching your configuration to your inverter's specifications. Every inverter has:
A maximum input voltage (never exceed this!)
A minimum voltage for operation
An MPPT voltage range for optimal performance
Maximum current limitations
"For Ahmed's coffee shop system with six 330W panels and a 3kW inverter, let's calculate the optimal configuration:
"Each panel is rated at 37.4V Vmp, 8.82A Imp "The inverter has an MPPT range of 120-500V and maximum input of 550V
"If we connect all six panels in series:
Total Vmp = 6 × 37.4V = 224.4V (within MPPT range)
Total Voc at cold temperature = 6 × 46V × 1.15 = 317.4V (below maximum)
Total current = 8.82A (within inverter capabilities)
"This would be a good configuration. However, if we had more panels or a different inverter, we might need a series-parallel arrangement.
"Remember that voltage increases in cold weather - we typically add 15-25% to account for cold morning conditions even in Mosul. Exceeding inverter maximum voltage can damage the equipment immediately.
"Conversely, on hot summer days in Mosul when panel temperatures can exceed 70°C, voltage drops significantly. Your system must maintain minimum voltage even under these conditions."
Financial Context to Include: "Proper string sizing has direct financial implications:
"Operating within the inverter's MPPT range optimizes power harvest. Systems operating outside this range can lose 5-15% efficiency, directly reducing financial returns.
"For Ahmed's coffee shop system producing electricity worth approximately 2,400,000 IQD annually, a 10% loss from improper string configuration would cost 240,000 IQD every year.
"Matching strings properly also extends equipment life. Inverters working at the edges of their operating range experience more stress and often fail prematurely. Replacing a 3kW inverter might cost 1,000,000-1,500,000 IQD - far more than the time investment to calculate proper configuration."
Stories to Share/Mistakes to Highlight: "Last year, I was called to troubleshoot a system in Al-Mansour district that was significantly underperforming. The installer had connected all panels in parallel, creating high current but low voltage. During Mosul's hot summer days, the voltage dropped below the inverter's minimum operating voltage for several hours daily, essentially shutting down the system during peak production hours.
"Another common mistake is failing to account for temperature effects. This system in Al-Jadida had eight panels in series. In winter when a cold morning followed a clear night, the open circuit voltage exceeded the inverter's maximum, damaging its input stage. The repair cost nearly half the price of a new inverter.
"Look at this system design from a commercial installation. The installer mixed different panel models in the same string. The different electrical characteristics caused the entire string to perform at the level of the weakest panel, reducing output by more than 20% compared to proper configuration."
Common Questions & Answers:
Q: What happens if one panel in a series string is shaded?
 A: Without optimizers or microinverters, a shaded panel can significantly reduce the output of the entire string - the string performs at the level of its weakest panel. This is why shade analysis is so important.
Q: Can I mix different panel models or sizes in one system?
 A: It's best to use identical panels in each string. If you must mix models, place different models in separate strings connected to separate MPPT inputs on the inverter.
Q: How many panels can I safely connect in series?
 A: This depends entirely on the inverter specifications and the panel voltage. Calculate both the operating voltage (Vmp) and the maximum open circuit voltage (Voc) with temperature correction to ensure you stay within the inverter's limits.
